The Office of the President is responsible for managing the governmentâs policy toward the press, but [[freedom of speech]] and [[freedom of the press]] are enshrined in the 1987 constitution. Although independent observers credit the government with respecting freedom of the press in general, the government has been criticized for failing to investigate thoroughly summary killings of [[journalists]] and for subjecting journalists to harassment and surveillance. The most widely read newspapers are the [[Manila Bulletin]], [[The Philippine Star]], [[Philippine Daily Inquirer]], [[The Manila Times]], and [[BusinessWorld]].
==Growth==
In 2004 the country had '''225 television stations''', '''369 AM radio broadcast stations''', '''583 FM radio broadcast stations''', '''10 internet radio stations''' and '''5''' '''[[shortwave]]''' '''stations'''. Although some media outlets, such as [[Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation|IBC]] (television) and the [[Philippine Broadcasting Service]] (radio), are government-run, most outlets are privately owned. Much media ownership is concentrated in the hands of prominent families and businesses. Consequently, some reports tend to be one-sided presentations favoring special interests. The privately owned press also tends toward sensationalism at times. <ref name=cp>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Philippines.pdf Philippines country profile].
